Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Acquisition of X-Ray Powder Diffraction Instrumentation with Heating Stage to Support Solution Calorimetric Research and Undergraduate Research on Mineral Thermal Expansion
Award.AbstractNarration:
1028953
Hovis

This grant supports acquisition of a power x-ray diffractometer with temperature controlled sample cell to permit kinetic studies of phase changes and crystallographic structure characterization of important rock forming minerals at Lafayette College. The XRD would complement the PIs calorimetric investigations of the thermodynamic behavior of solid solutions of silicates including mics, feldspars and feldspathoids and zeolites. Experimental thermodynamic data informs models of behavior of phases in the deep crust and XRD studies will elucidate the crystallographic and crystal-chemical principles that govern thermal expansion of Earth important mineral solid solutions. The PI at this undergraduate institution actively engages students in experiential learning with state-of-the-art techniques in crystallography and thermodynamics and their application to scientific research problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant was used to purchase an X-ray powder diffraction unit, namely PANalytical's Empyrean model. The purchase of this X-ray unit was to serve three purposes:

1. Support solution calorimetric research of the principal investigator in providing an instrument that was capable of giving robust characterization of the materials studied in the latter work. Indeed, the X-ray unit has been used extensively to characterize multiple members of F-OH, F-Cl, and Cl-OH apatite solid solution series. It also has been used to characterize an extensive array of Al-Si ordered and disordered alkali feldspars.

2. To determine the systematics of thermal expansion in same-structure mineral groups, namely how expansion characteristics of minerals within the various groups are affected by chemical composition. The idea here was to develop predictive parameters that would allow scientists to accurately predict thermal expansion coefficients of minerals without having to actually measure them simply by knowing mineral ID and chemical compositon. Toward this end, during the present grant period we have collected data on numerous members of various silicate groups including pyroxenes, tourmalines, olivines, garnets, amphiboles, and micas. We also have collected data on F-OH and F-Cl apatites. Data on apatite have been published in two papers in a peer-reviewed journal called the American Mineralogist. Data on pyroxenes and tourmalines have been presented at Geological Society of America scientific meetings. Data on olivine and garnet are complete in every respect, but have not yet been presented publically. Data collection on amphiboles and micas has been completed, but data reduction is ongoing. We expect to prepare all of the latter for journal submission in less than a year from now.

3. To train undergraduate students to do research well and responsibly, and to help such students maintain interest in science. During the present grant period, no fewer than seven students (3 female and 4 male) have been involved in this research. Five of those students have graduated, three going to graduate school, one entering the environmental geology field, and the fifth working for the U.S. Forest Service. The remaining two students have not yet graduated, but both expect to attend graduate school in the geological sciences.

As a bonus, the new X-ray unit has served Lafayette College at large, supporting both student and faculty research. So far, this has included students/faculty in chemistry, chemical engineering, and geology, but many more are sure to benefit in the future, as this is the only X-ray unit on campus and is expected to be useful for at least another 20 years. The new X-ray unit also has been used in course work in geology (mineralogy, petrology, and senior thesis) and chemistry. Students have enjoyed using and been inspired by this new highly sophisticated instrumentation.

The minerals obtained for this work mostly have come from the Smithsonian Institution, as well as the American Museum of Natural History. There are several specific principles that we have learned so far about mineral thermal expansion, as we continue to reduce and understand the data that we have produced:

1. In the apatite mineral group: Even if volume thermal expansion is not much affected by chemical composition, the same is not true of individual unit-cell axes, as there can be different and compensating expansion mechanisms along various crystallographic axes.

2. In silicate mineral systems, the presence of a major amount of ferrous iron in a mineral seems to have a significant impact on thermal expansion behavior, as this is one of the larger (and most abundant) ions that can substitute in a six-coordinated crystallographic site.
